stages.headline: Welcome! In this lesson we will use the Pythagorean theorem /K a^2 + b^2 = c^2 K/ and practice percent calculations.
Here is a right triangle with legs /K a K/ and /K b K/, and hypotenuse /K c K/.
If /K a = 3 K/ and /K b = 4 K/, find the hypotenuse /K c K/. Show your work on the board and write your final result.
stages.problemText: Solve for the hypotenuse c in a right triangle with legs a = 3 and b = 4 by applying the Pythagorean theorem.
stages.solutionSteps: Write a^2 + b^2 = c^2. Substitute 3 and 4 to get 3^2 + 4^2 = c^2. Compute 9 + 16 = 25. Take the square root to get c = 5.

stages.headline: Concept check: Which statement best explains why the hypotenuse is always the longest side in a right triangle?

choices: Because the hypotenuse is opposite the right angle and its length is determined by adding the squares of the legs.
Because it is the side drawn first when sketching a triangle.
Because the triangle inequality says the smallest side must be opposite the right angle.
optionsQuiz.feedbackCorrect: Great explanation. Opposite the right angle and defined by a^2 + b^2 = c^2.

stages.problemText: Choose the best conceptual explanation for why the hypotenuse is the longest side.
stages.correctAnswer: Because the hypotenuse is opposite the right angle and its length is determined by adding the squares of the legs.
stages.solutionSteps: Use properties of right triangles and the Pythagorean theorem to justify that c^2 = a^2 + b^2 implies c > a and c > b.

acceptable_forms: Because the hypotenuse is opposite the right angle and its length is determined by adding the squares of the legs.
common_misconceptions: confusing drawing order with geometric properties

wrongAnswerRationales.1: Sketching order has no geometric consequence for side length.
wrongAnswerRationales.2: The triangle inequality is true, but it does not say the smallest side is opposite the right angle. In right triangles, c is longest because c^2 = a^2 + b^2.
